title: Double slit - light of frequency f

content.question: Light of frequency <math alttext="f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>f</mi></math> having planar wave fronts are incident on a double slit, as shown in the figure. Beyond the slits, the light is found to travel in three directions. Some of the light travels in the same direction as the original light. Other parts of the light are traveling in directions that are an angle <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> from the original direction, where <math alttext="theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>θ</mi></math> is NOT a small angle. What is the distance between the centers of the slits?

choices.label: <math alttext="the fraction c over f theta, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>
<math alttext="f over sine of theta" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>f</mi><mrow><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>

<math alttext="the fraction c over f sine of theta, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>

content.answer: <math alttext="the fraction c over f sine of theta, end fraction" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mi>c</mi><mrow><mi>f</mi><mspace width="0.2em"></mspace><mi>sin</mi><mo>⁡</mo><mi>θ</mi></mrow></mfrac></math>
